holdings.text: The Supplementary Covenant is void and inoperative because the Rulers had surrendered completely all their sovereign powers to the new State under the original Covenant.

anchor.surface_text: But it is argued for the appellants that the Supplementary Covenant is void and inoperative because by the Covenant dated May 5, 1948, the Rulers had surrendered companypletely all their sovereign powers to the new State

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article VI of original Covenant effects complete divestiture of sovereign rights to Union on August 20, 1948; no residual sovereignty for later treaty; distinguishes international law on interim authority.

holdings.text: Even assuming validity determined by original Covenant, the dispute arises out of a provision in the Covenant and Art. 363 bars jurisdiction of civil courts.

anchor.surface_text: even on the footing that the Validity of the impugned Act, should be determined in accordance with the provisions of the original Covenant, without reference to the Supplementary Covenant, the appellants must fail because the question in dispute is one which arises out of a provision in a Covenant and under Art. 363

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability under Act challenged via Art. X of Covenant; distinguishes Bholanath where right independent of Covenant.

holdings.text: Impugned Act continues in force proprio vigore in erstwhile Patiala territories despite lapse of Ordinances.

anchor.surface_text: But even if the appellants are right in their contention that Ordinances 1 and 16 of 2005 Bk ceased to be in operation after the expiry of six months from the date of their promulgation, they can derive no advantage from it, because what those Ordinances did was to extend the operation of all Patiala laws to the territories which had formed part of the other Covenanting States. So far as the territories of the erstwhile State of Patiala are concerned, its laws continued to be in force proprio vigore

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinances extended Patiala laws to other states; Patiala laws independent of Ordinances.

holdings.text: Patiala State Bank forms a separate class justifying special recovery procedure; does not violate Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed that the impugned Act and the rules framed thereunder put the Patiala State Bank in a position different from that of the other Banks under the ordinary law. The question is whether this difference amounts to discrimination within Art. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State Bank uses public funds needing speedy recovery like revenue; rational nexus; cites Chiranjit Lal, Ram Krishna Dalmia, Mannalal.

holdings.text: No discrimination under Art. 14 post States Reorganisation Act due to historical geographical classification.
